an10.199-210:1.1.pli: “Dasahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato puggalo na sevitabbo.
an10.199-210:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should not associate with an individual who has ten qualities.

an10.199-210:1.3.pli: Pāṇātipātī hoti, adinnādāyī hoti, kāmesumicchācārī hoti, musāvādī hoti, pisuṇavāco hoti, pharusavāco hoti, samphappalāpī hoti, abhijjhālu hoti, byāpannacitto hoti, micchādiṭṭhiko hoti—
an10.199-210:1.3.eng: They kill living creatures, steal, and commit sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view.

an10.199-210:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato puggalo na sevitabbo.
an10.199-210:1.4.eng: You should not associate with an individual who has these ten qualities.

an10.199-210:2.1.pli: Dasahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato puggalo sevitabbo.
an10.199-210:2.1.eng: You should associate with an individual who has ten qualities.

an10.199-210:2.3.pli: Pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, anabhijjhālu hoti, abyāpannacitto hoti, sammādiṭṭhiko hoti—
an10.199-210:2.3.eng: They don’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. They’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view.

an10.199-210:2.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato puggalo sevitabbo.
an10.199-210:2.4.eng: You should associate with an individual who has these ten qualities.”

an10.199-210:3.1.pli: Dasahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato puggalo na bhajitabbo …pe…
an10.199-210:3.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should not frequent an individual who has ten qualities …

an10.199-210:4.1.pli: Dasahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato puggalo bahuṃ apuññaṃ pasavati …
an10.199-210:4.1.eng: “An individual who possesses these ten qualities brims with much wickedness. …

an10.199-210:4.2.eng: An individual who possesses these ten qualities brims with much merit.

an10.199-210:4.4.pli: Pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, anabhijjhālu hoti, abyāpannacitto hoti, sammādiṭṭhiko hoti—
an10.199-210:4.4.eng: They don’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. They’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view.

an10.199-210:4.5.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato puggalo bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavatī”ti.
an10.199-210:4.5.eng: An individual who has these ten qualities creates much merit.”

an10.2:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethical conduct, need not make a wish:

an10.2:1.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ sīlavato sīlasampannassa avippaṭisāro uppajjati.
an10.2:1.3.eng: It’s only natural that an ethical person has no regrets.

an10.2:1.4.eng: When you have no regrets you need not make a wish:

an10.2:1.6.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ avippaṭisārissa pāmojjaṃ jāyati.
an10.2:1.6.eng: It’s only natural that joy springs up when you have no regrets.

an10.2:1.7.eng: When you feel joy you need not make a wish:

an10.2:1.9.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ pamuditassa pīti uppajjati.
an10.2:1.9.eng: It’s only natural that rapture arises when you’re joyful.

an10.2:1.10.eng: When your mind is full of rapture you need not make a wish:

an10.2:1.12.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ pītimanassa kāyo passambhati.
an10.2:1.12.eng: It’s only natural that your body becomes tranquil when your mind is full of rapture.

an10.2:1.13.eng: When your body is tranquil you need not make a wish:

an10.2:1.15.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati.
an10.2:1.15.eng: It’s only natural to feel bliss when your body is tranquil.

an10.2:1.16.eng: When you feel bliss you need not make a wish:

an10.2:1.17.eng: ‘May my mind be immersed in samādhi!’

an10.2:1.18.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
an10.2:1.18.eng: It’s only natural for the mind to be immersed in samādhi when you feel bliss.

an10.2:1.19.eng: When your mind is immersed in samādhi you need not make a wish:

an10.2:1.21.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ samāhito yathābhūtaṃ jānāti passati.
an10.2:1.21.eng: It’s only natural to truly know and see when your mind is immersed in samādhi.

an10.2:1.22.pli: Yathābhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, jānato passato na cetanāya karaṇīyaṃ:
an10.2:1.22.eng: When you truly know and see you need not make a wish:

an10.2:1.24.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ yathābhūtaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ nibbindati virajjati.
an10.2:1.24.eng: It’s only natural to become disillusioned and dispassionate when you truly know and see.

an10.2:1.25.pli: Nibbinnassa, bhikkhave, virattassa na cetanāya karaṇīyaṃ:
an10.2:1.25.eng: When you’re disillusioned and dispassionate you need not make a wish:

an10.2:1.26.eng: ‘May I realize the knowledge and vision of freedom!’

an10.2:1.27.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yaṃ nibbinno viratto vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ sacchikaroti.
an10.2:1.27.eng: It’s only natural to realize the knowledge and vision of freedom when you’re disillusioned and dispassionate.

an10.2:2.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, nibbidāvirāgo vimuttiñāṇadassanattho vimuttiñāṇadassanānisaṃso;
an10.2:2.1.eng: And so, mendicants, the knowledge and vision of freedom is the purpose and benefit of disillusionment and dispassion.

an10.2:2.2.eng: Disillusionment and dispassion is the purpose and benefit of truly knowing and seeing.

an10.2:2.3.eng: Truly knowing and seeing is the purpose and benefit of immersion.

an10.2:2.4.eng: Immersion is the purpose and benefit of bliss.

an10.2:2.5.eng: Bliss is the purpose and benefit of tranquility.

an10.2:2.6.eng: Tranquility is the purpose and benefit of rapture.

an10.2:2.7.eng: Rapture is the purpose and benefit of joy.

an10.2:2.8.eng: Joy is the purpose and benefit of not having regrets.

an10.2:2.9.eng: Not having regrets is the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics.

an10.2:2.10.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, dhammā dhamme abhisandenti, dhammā dhamme paripūrenti apārā pāraṃ gamanāyā”ti.
an10.2:2.10.eng: And so, mendicants, good qualities flow on and fill up from one to the other, for going from the near shore to the far shore.”

an10.20:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammaṃ nāma kurūnaṃ nigamo.
an10.20:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.

an10.20:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

an10.20:2.1.pli: “Dasayime, bhikkhave, ariyāvāsā, ye ariyā āvasiṃsu vā āvasanti vā āvasissanti vā.
an10.20:2.1.eng: “There are these ten abodes of the noble ones in which the noble ones of the past, present, and future abide.

an10.20:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hoti, chaḷaṅgasamannāgato, ekārakkho, caturāpasseno, paṇunnapaccekasacco, samavayasaṭṭhesano, anāvilasaṅkappo, passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro, suvimuttacitto, suvimuttapañño.
an10.20:2.3.eng: A mendicant has given up five factors, possesses six factors, has a single guard, has four supports, has cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has unsullied intentions, has stilled the physical process, and is well freed in mind and well freed by wisdom.

an10.20:3.1.eng: And how has a mendicant given up five factors?

an10.20:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno kāmacchando pahīno hoti, byāpādo pahīno hoti, thinamiddhaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, vicikicchā pahīnā hoti.
an10.20:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has given up sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

an10.20:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hoti.
an10.20:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has given up five factors.

an10.20:4.1.eng: And how does a mendicant possess six factors?

an10.20:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
an10.20:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

an10.20:4.3.eng: Hearing a sound with their ears …

an10.20:4.4.eng: Smelling an odor with their nose …

an10.20:4.5.eng: Tasting a flavor with their tongue …

an10.20:4.6.eng: Feeling a touch with their body …

an10.20:4.7.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
an10.20:4.7.eng: Knowing an idea with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

an10.20:4.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chaḷaṅgasamannāgato hoti.
an10.20:4.8.eng: That’s how a mendicant possesses six factors.

an10.20:5.1.eng: And how does a mendicant have a single guard?

an10.20:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satārakkhena cetasā samannāgato hoti.
an10.20:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant’s heart is guarded by mindfulness.

an10.20:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ekārakkho hoti.
an10.20:5.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has a single guard.

an10.20:6.1.eng: And how does a mendicant have four supports?

an10.20:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saṅkhāyekaṃ paṭisevati, saṅkhāyekaṃ adhivāseti, saṅkhāyekaṃ parivajjeti, saṅkhāyekaṃ vinodeti.
an10.20:6.2.eng: After appraisal, a mendicant uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.

an10.20:6.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu caturāpasseno hoti.
an10.20:6.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has four supports.

an10.20:7.1.eng: And how has a mendicant cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth?

an10.20:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno yāni tāni puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ puthupaccekasaccāni, seyyathidaṃ:
an10.20:7.2.eng: Different ascetics and brahmins have different idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth. For example:

an10.20:7.3.pli: ‘sassato loko’ti vā, ‘asassato loko’ti vā, ‘antavā loko’ti vā, ‘anantavā loko’ti vā, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti vā, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti vā, ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā,
an10.20:7.3.eng: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are one and the same, or the soul is one thing, the body another; after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.

an10.20:7.4.pli: sabbāni tāni nunnāni honti paṇunnāni cattāni vantāni muttāni pahīnāni paṭinissaṭṭhāni.
an10.20:7.4.eng: A mendicant has cast out, cast aside, thrown out, discarded, let go of, given up, and relinquished all these.

an10.20:7.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṇunnapaccekasacco hoti.
an10.20:7.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant has cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth.

an10.20:8.1.eng: And how has a mendicant totally given up searching?

an10.20:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno kāmesanā pahīnā hoti, bhavesanā pahīnā hoti, brahmacariyesanā paṭippassaddhā.
an10.20:8.2.eng: It’s when they’ve given up searching for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual life.

an10.20:8.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu samavayasaṭṭhesano hoti.
an10.20:8.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has totally given up searching.

an10.20:9.1.eng: And how does a mendicant have unsullied intentions?

an10.20:9.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno kāmasaṅkappo pahīno hoti, byāpādasaṅkappo pahīno hoti, vihiṃsāsaṅkappo pahīno hoti.
an10.20:9.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has given up intentions of sensuality, malice, and cruelty.

an10.20:9.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anāvilasaṅkappo hoti.
an10.20:9.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has unsullied intentions.

an10.20:10.1.eng: And how has a mendicant stilled the physical process?

an10.20:10.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an10.20:10.2.eng: It’s when, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

an10.20:10.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro hoti.
an10.20:10.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has stilled the physical process.

an10.20:11.1.eng: And how is a mendicant well freed in mind?

an10.20:11.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno rāgā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti, dosā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti, mohā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti.
an10.20:11.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant’s mind is freed from greed, hate, and delusion.

an10.20:11.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu suvimuttacitto hoti.
an10.20:11.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is well freed in mind.

an10.20:12.1.eng: And how is a mendicant well freed by wisdom?

an10.20:12.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘rāgo me pahīno ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo’ti pajānāti, doso me pahīno …pe… ‘moho me pahīno ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo’ti pajānāti.
an10.20:12.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant understands: ‘I’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.’

an10.20:12.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu suvimuttapañño hoti.
an10.20:12.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant’s mind is well freed by wisdom.

an10.20:13.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ ariyā ariyāvāse āvasiṃsu, sabbe te imeva dasa ariyāvāse āvasiṃsu;
an10.20:13.1.eng: Mendicants, whether in the past, future, or present, all noble ones abide in these same ten abodes of the noble ones.

an10.20:13.2.pli: ye hi keci, bhikkhave, anāgatamaddhānaṃ ariyā ariyāvāse āvasissanti, sabbe te imeva dasa ariyāvāse āvasissanti;

an10.20:13.3.pli: ye hi keci, bhikkhave, etarahi ariyā ariyāvāse āvasanti, sabbe te imeva dasa ariyāvāse āvasanti.

an10.20:13.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dasa ariyāvāsā, ye ariyā āvasiṃsu vā āvasanti vā āvasissanti vā”ti.
an10.20:13.4.eng: These are the ten abodes of the noble ones in which the noble ones of the past, present, and future abide.”

an10.21:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, towards evening the lion, king of beasts, emerges from his den,

an10.21:1.4.pli: Samantā catuddisaṃ anuviloketvā tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati.
an10.21:1.4.eng: and roars his lion’s roar three times.

an10.21:1.5.eng: Then he sets out on the hunt.

an10.21:1.7.eng: ‘May I not injure any little creatures on unclear ground.’

an10.21:2.1.pli: ‘Sīho’ti kho, bhikkhave, tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
an10.21:2.1.eng: ‘Lion’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

an10.21:2.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tathāgato parisāya dhammaṃ deseti, idamassa hoti sīhanādasmiṃ.
an10.21:2.2.eng: When the Realized One teaches Dhamma to an assembly, this is his lion’s roar.

an10.21:3.1.pli: Dasayimāni, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalāni, yehi balehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an10.21:3.1.eng: The Realized One possesses ten powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

an10.21:3.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an10.21:3.3.eng: Firstly, the Realized One truly understands the possible as possible and the impossible as impossible.

an10.21:3.4.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an10.21:3.4.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

an10.21:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an10.21:4.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the result of deeds undertaken in the past, future, and present in terms of grounds and causes.

an10.21:4.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an10.21:4.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an10.21:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato sabbatthagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an10.21:5.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands where all paths of practice lead.

an10.21:5.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato sabbatthagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an10.21:5.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an10.21:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato anekadhātuṃ nānādhātuṃ lokaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an10.21:6.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the world with its many and diverse elements.

an10.21:6.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato anekadhātuṃ nānādhātuṃ lokaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti …pe… brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an10.21:6.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an10.21:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato sattānaṃ nānādhimuttikataṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an10.21:7.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the diverse convictions of sentient beings.

an10.21:7.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato sattānaṃ nānādhimuttikataṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti …pe… brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an10.21:7.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an10.21:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ indriyaparopariyattaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an10.21:8.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the faculties of other sentient beings and other individuals after encompassing them with his mind.

an10.21:8.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ indriyaparopariyattaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti …pe… brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an10.21:8.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an10.21:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ saṅkilesaṃ vodānaṃ vuṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an10.21:9.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands corruption, cleansing, and emergence regarding the absorptions, liberations, immersions, and attainments.

an10.21:9.2.pli: Yampi …pe… pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti …pe… brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an10.21:9.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an10.21:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe, ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti, iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
an10.21:10.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. He remembers: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ Thus he recollects his many past lives, with features and details.

an10.21:10.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an10.21:10.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an10.21:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā; ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
an10.21:11.1.eng: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Realized One sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds. ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, he sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

an10.21:11.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an10.21:11.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an10.21:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an10.21:12.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an10.21:12.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an10.21:12.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an10.21:13.1.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, dasa tathāgatassa tathāgatabalāni, yehi balehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavattetī”ti.
an10.21:13.1.eng: These are the ten powers of a Realized One that the Realized One possesses. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.”
